title: 114_hr3974
content: The "Grow Our Own Directive: Physician Assistant Employment and Education Act of 2016" allows for a pilot program to provide educational assistance to physician assistants employed at the Department of Veterans Affairs. The "Grow Our Own Directive" pilot program provides educational assistance to former members of the Armed Forces to become physician assistants at the Department of Veterans Affairs. Eligible individuals must have medical or military health experience. The pilot program for former Armed Forces members aims to train physician assistants at the Department of Veterans Affairs. Eligible individuals must have medical or military health experience, relevant education in healthcare, and participation in healthcare services. The program will run for five years after enactment. The Secretary will select at least 250 eligible individuals for the pilot program, giving priority to those who participated in a previous program or agree to work as a physician assistant for the Veterans Health Administration in designated communities. The pilot program provides educational assistance for individuals in medically underserved populations in states with a high percentage of veterans to obtain a master's degree in physician assistant studies or a similar field. The Secretary will use existing programs and scholarships to provide educational assistance to individuals in the pilot program, who must agree to a period of obligated service. The pilot program requires individuals to agree to work as physician assistants for the Veterans Health Administration for a specified period of obligated service, which can vary depending on the program they are participating in. If the program does not specify a period, the obligated service is three years. The pilot program requires individuals to work as physician assistants for the Veterans Health Administration for a specified period of obligated service, which can vary. If an individual fails to satisfy this period, they are liable to repay the amount received under the program, with exceptions for certain circumstances. The pilot program requires individuals to work as physician assistants for the Veterans Health Administration for a specified period of obligated service. The Secretary will ensure mentors are available for participants, and seek partnerships with institutions offering relevant degree programs. The pilot program requires individuals to work as physician assistants for the Veterans Health Administration for a specified period of obligated service. Institutions offering programs in physician assistant studies must agree to guarantee seats for participants and provide information on admissions criteria. The pilot program for physician assistants at the Veterans Health Administration requires individuals to work for a specified period. The program is administered by the Secretary through the Office of Physician Assistant Services, appointing a Deputy Director for Education and Career Development of Physician Assistants. The pilot program for physician assistants at the Veterans Health Administration is overseen by a physician assistant who is responsible for recruiting candidates, coordinating with participants, assisting in applying to a master's degree program, and providing information to eligible individuals. The physician assistant may also be employed in the field at a medical facility. The Deputy Director of Recruitment and Retention, a physician assistant and veteran employed by the Department, is responsible for coordinating the needs of the pilot program, providing mentors to participants, and identifying employment positions and mentors for participants at Veterans Health Administration facilities. An administrative assistant at a medical center of the Department, compensated at a rate not less than level GS-6, assists with administrative duties for the pilot program. An administrative assistant at a medical center assists with administrative duties for the pilot program to ensure effective operation. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will submit a report to Congress on the pilot program's effectiveness in improving eligible individuals' ability to become physician assistants. The pilot program aims to enable individuals with medical skills gained in the Armed Forces to become physician assistants and help address the shortage of physician assistants in the Department. The Secretaries of Veterans Affairs, Labor, Defense, and Health and Human Services will identify necessary modifications to meet these goals. The pilot program aims to provide educational assistance to former members of the Armed Forces to become physician assistants in the Department of Veterans Affairs. The program will be assessed to determine if it can be a model for other Department programs in healthcare fields. The title of the bill will be amended to reflect this focus.
